items.title: Avatar: Fire and Ash is big, goofy and forgettable
items.summary_auto: Avatar: Fire and Ash — James Cameron's newest entry in his wildly successful franchise — has exciting action, beautiful effects and little to remember.

items.title: Canadian delegation, including MPs, denied entry into West Bank
Canadian delegation of MPs denied entry into West Bank
items.summary_auto: A delegation of 30 Canadians, including six MPs, has been denied entry into the West Bank early Tuesday.

items.title: Ribbon skirt Barbie donation delights Regina family in time for Christmas
items.summary_auto: Christmas came early at the North Central Family Centre in Regina for sisters Mya and Kimberly Kirkness-Henry. They were the first to receive Barbies with handmade ribbon skirts that were anonymously donated by two women.

items.title: Bill before Senate would recognize First Nations jurisdiction over gaming
items.summary_auto: Some First Nations leaders in Saskatchewan say a bill before the Senate that would give them full control over gambling on reserves will help their economic independence.

items.title: The NSLC had a deal for a Mi’kmaq-run cannabis shop, but the band is tapping the brakes
items.summary_auto: The Crown corporation in charge of cannabis sales in Nova Scotia has signed an agreement with a Mi'kmaw community for what would be a first-of-its-kind on-reserve shop owned by the band, but the chief says it’s now on hold.

items.title: N.S. flu season expected to peak earlier this year, says province's top doctor
items.summary_auto: Dr. Robert Strang, Nova Scotia's chief medical officer of health, says this year's flu season is expected to hit its peak earlier and could be worse than it usually is.

items.title: Toronto councillors consider maximum ban for contractor that overbilled city $1.1M
items.summary_auto: Toronto city councillors are set to decide the fate of a contractor that intentionally overbilled the city more than $1 million, a breach of the supplier code of conduct uncovered by a forensic audit conducted for the city.

items.title: Ontario wants to bring in more attractions to Niagara with 'multibillion-dollar' plan
items.summary_auto: Premier Doug Ford was in Niagara Falls, Ont., Monday announcing a tourism strategy that aims to add new attractions and service expansions in the area.

items.title: Ottawa to announce plan to slash methane pollution from fossil fuel production, landfills
items.summary_auto: The Carney government is making good on a promise to help tackle one of the most potent forms of climate pollution, as it announces new measures to tackle the methane emissions released by landfills and oil and gas facilities.

items.title: Why is the U.K. rethinking puberty blockers?
items.summary_auto: Today, an in-depth look at puberty blockers and their use on minors with gender dysphoria. These drugs have come under an enormous amount of scrutiny in recent years, with some questioning their benefits, safety and long-term impact. After banning the use of puberty blockers for gender treatment of people under 18, a new clinical trial in the U.K. aims to get to the bottom of those concerns. Azeen Ghorayshi is a science and gender reporter for the New York Times.

items.title: Threats in the hall, blood on the floor: 'Trauma Tower' racks up most police calls in Kingston
items.summary_auto: A highrise run by the Kingston & Frontenac Housing Corporation is a hotbed for police activity, with hundreds of calls for service  this year alone. Officials say changes are coming, but one resident says she still lives in fear.

items.title: Hundreds of Quebec seniors' homes lack required safeguards to prevent wandering
items.summary_auto: Nearly half of Quebec seniors’ residences that house people at risk of wandering still lack the provincially mandated security measures meant to reduce that risk, Radio-Canada has learned. The recent death of an 88-year-old woman outside a seniors’ residence in Laval, Que., has raised questions about compliance with regulations first announced in 2022 by the Health Ministry.

items.title: Ottawa approves merger of Teck and Anglo American
items.summary_auto: Shareholders last week gave their blessing to the plan, which was first announced in September, to create Anglo Teck, a $70-billion copper mining powerhouse.

items.title: Trump sues BBC for defamation over editing of pre-riot speech, seeking up to $10B US
Trump declares fentanyl a 'weapon of mass destruction' with executive order
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday declaring fentanyl a weapon of mass destruction, a move that dramatically expands the U.S. government's authority to fight the synthetic opioid blamed for tens of thousands of American overdose deaths each year.

items.title: Quebec teachers say they’re targeted by violence, verbal abuse in schools
items.summary_auto: Teachers across the province are warning of increased violence directed toward them inside classrooms. A major teachers’ union released a survey documenting the trend and is reaching out to the province for help.

items.title: Christmas miracle? Taco Bell scheduled to open N.L. location in late December
items.summary_auto: Taco Bell has been the talk of the town for months. Now, Mount Pearl is getting close to having a new location open. The CBC’s Jenna Head reports.

items.title: What we know about Nick Reiner, in custody following his parents' deaths
items.summary_auto: Nick struggled with drug addiction and homelessness from the time he was a teenager, and made a film in his 20s alongside his dad about a young man's struggles with addiction. Los Angeles Police said Monday that Nick was in custody related to their death and was being held without bail.

items.title: U.S. offers security guarantees to Kyiv, says Russia not opposed to Ukraine joining EU
items.summary_auto: The U.S. has agreed to provide unspecified security guarantees to Ukraine as part of a peace deal to end Russia's nearly four-year war, and more talks are likely this weekend, U.S. officials said Monday following the latest discussions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Berlin.

items.title: Family of Ontario man whose 2016 jail death sparked inquest still waiting for apology from province
Ontario has no plans to sell off stored U.S. alcohol for charity, Ford says
items.summary_auto: Ontario Premier Doug Ford says his government has no plan to sell off a stockpile of American alcohol sitting in storage to benefit charities over the holiday season, for fear it could harm local producers.

items.title: Saskatoon teen admits to lighting classmate on fire in 2024
items.summary_auto: A Saskatoon teen is admitting she planned and executed a fiery assault on a classmate at Evan Hardy Collegiate in September 2024.

items.title: National home sales fell in November with housing activity in 'holding pattern,' says CREA
items.summary_auto: National home sales fell 10.7 per cent in November compared with the same month last year, as the Canadian Real Estate Association says activity has veered into a "holding pattern" heading into 2026.

items.title: Anti-Kremlin punk band Pussy Riot designated an extremist group by Russian court
items.summary_auto: The Russian anti-Kremlin feminist punk band and art collective known as Pussy Riot was designated an extremist organization by a Moscow court on Monday, banning its activities inside Russia as part of a wider crackdown on dissenting voices.
